sampleQuestions.title: How can I distinguish between natural and cultural layers in stratigraphy?
sampleQuestions.body: I'm working on a site with complex stratigraphy and having trouble distinguishing between natural geological deposits and cultural layers. Are there specific indicators I should be looking for?
answers: Look for changes in soil texture, color, and composition. Cultural layers often contain artifacts, charcoal, or evidence of human alteration. Micro-morphology analysis can also be very helpful in distinguishing between natural and cultural deposits.

sampleQuestions.title: How to identify quartz from feldspar in field conditions?
sampleQuestions.body: As a beginner geologist, I'm having trouble distinguishing between quartz and feldspar when doing field work. What are some practical tips for identification without lab equipment?
answers: Quartz is harder (7 on Mohs scale) and won't scratch with a steel knife, while feldspar (6-6.5) will. Quartz also lacks cleavage and shows conchoidal fracture.
Try the 'teeth test' - quartz feels colder to the touch than feldspar due to its higher thermal conductivity.
